sections.title: Benefits of Image-Guided Surgery by Cancer Stage
sections.tldr: Image-guided surgery offers distinct advantages across different cancer stages, with early-stage cancers benefiting from precise tumor removal with tissue preservation, while advanced stages utilize imaging for treatment monitoring and adaptive therapy approaches. These stage-specific benefits help optimize surgical outcomes by ensuring complete tumor removal in early disease and guiding more complex treatment decisions in advanced cases. (7 sources)
sections.text:
Image-guided surgery (IGS) provides unique benefits depending on the stage of cancer, allowing for more personalized and effective treatment approaches. For early-stage cancers, particularly stage I and II breast cancers, IGS enables Breast Conserving Surgery (BCS) that precisely removes tumors while preserving surrounding healthy tissue. This approach relies on various medical imaging systems to localize tumors with greater accuracy than physical examination alone, resulting in improved outcomes <Paper corpusId="218675197" paperTitle="(Kosik et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="11774716" paperTitle="(Ananthakrishnan et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>.

The detection of smaller, earlier-stage cancers through advanced imaging technologies has facilitated a trend toward less aggressive treatment options with promising effectiveness and reduced morbidity. For patients concerned about cosmetic outcomes after traditional breast-conservation therapy, minimally invasive ablation techniques guided by imaging can achieve similar efficacy with better cosmetic results. These approaches are particularly valuable for older patients with comorbidities that might make conventional surgery more risky <Paper corpusId="24372526" paperTitle="(Roubidoux et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

For advanced-stage cancers, image guidance plays a crucial role in determining the extent of disease and planning comprehensive treatment strategies. Surgery often forms part of a more extensive treatment approach that may include neoadjuvant or adjuvant therapies <Paper corpusId="246432806" paperTitle="(Lauwerends et al., 2022)" isShortName></Paper>. In these cases, imaging not only guides the surgical procedure but also helps monitor treatment response. For example, in breast cancer patients receiving neoadjuvant chemotherapy, an image-guided approach can be used to tailor treatment duration based on early response assessment, allowing for surgery to be performed after achieving radiologic complete response rather than completing a predetermined number of chemotherapy cycles <Paper corpusId="257326144" paperTitle="(Voort et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

Preoperative imaging significantly impacts treatment planning across all cancer stages. For breast cancer specifically, the extent and stage at initial presentation determine available treatment options and prognosis. While mammography and image-guided biopsy establish the baseline disease extent, additional imaging modalities such as MRI can reveal further multifocal or multicentric disease that might alter the surgical approach. Lymph node status, a critical prognostic factor, can be assessed through various imaging techniques including ultrasound, MRI, and nuclear medicine approaches like positron emission tomography (PET), though with variable accuracy <Paper corpusId="267861895" paperTitle="(Gilbert, 2002)" isShortName></Paper>.

For early-stage non-melanoma skin cancers (NMSCs), image-guided superficial radiotherapy (IGSRT) offers an alternative to surgical approaches, particularly beneficial for poor surgical candidates or patients who prefer to avoid surgery. IGSRT has been shown to be clinically equivalent to Mohs micrographic surgery and statistically superior to non-image-guided superficial radiotherapy for these early-stage cases <Paper corpusId="272548346" paperTitle="(Farberg et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

This is often accomplished by use of various medical imaging systems which permit the surgeon to localize the suspect lesion with better accuracy than physical examination alone (Hargreaves et al., 2014).

sections.title: Alternative and Complementary Treatment Modalities
sections.tldr: Beyond traditional surgery, cancer treatment includes options like image-guided thermal ablation, stereotactic radiotherapy, and dual-labeled antibody-guided interventions that offer alternatives for patients unsuitable for conventional approaches. These complementary modalities can provide effective treatment with reduced morbidity, particularly beneficial for high-risk patients or those with specific cancer types and stages. (10 sources)
sections.text:
## Stereotactic Radiotherapy
- Stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (SABR), also known as stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) or stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS), serves as a viable treatment option for high-risk patients with stage I non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), alongside surgical approaches and thermal ablation. <Paper corpusId="274697546" paperTitle="(Pennathur et al._1, 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="274768050" paperTitle="(Pennathur et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>
- Advanced radiotherapy technologies have enabled highly conformal techniques with dose escalation, though these approaches require careful management of potential toxicity to surrounding healthy tissues and geometric uncertainties that could lead to target volume underdosing. <Paper corpusId="259851434" paperTitle="(Hinojosa et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>
- Intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT), image-guided radiotherapy (IGRT), radioimmunotherapy, stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS), and stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT) represent substantial developments in radiation-based cancer treatments. <Paper corpusId="55378429" paperTitle="(Nawab, 2015)" isShortName></Paper>

## Image-Guided Thermal Ablation
- Image-guided thermal ablation (IGTA) provides an alternative to surgery for high-risk patients with stage I NSCLC, particularly those with peripheral tumors who are medically inoperable. <Paper corpusId="274628477" paperTitle="(Lanuti et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>
- IGTA may be especially beneficial for non-operable NSCLC patients with interstitial lung disease for whom radiation therapy poses excessive risk. The technique can be delivered through three methods: radiofrequency ablation (RFA), microwave ablation, and cryoablation. <Paper corpusId="274628477" paperTitle="(Lanuti et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>
- For high-risk patients with stage I NSCLC, an expert panel identified sublobar resection, stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (SABR), and image-guided thermal ablation (IGTA) as applicable treatment modalities, with treatment selection guided by specific lung nodule-related factors. <Paper corpusId="274623114" paperTitle="(Pennathur et al._2, 2024)" isShortName></Paper>

## Minimally Invasive Ablation Techniques
- For early-stage small tumors, minimally invasive ablation techniques aim to achieve efficacy similar to breast-conservation therapy while providing better cosmetic results. These approaches are particularly valuable for older patients with comorbidities that increase surgical risks. <Paper corpusId="24372526" paperTitle="(Roubidoux et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>
- The trend toward less aggressive treatment options for small breast cancers has been facilitated by improved imaging technologies and increased breast cancer screening, leading to the detection of smaller, earlier-stage cancers. <Paper corpusId="24372526" paperTitle="(Roubidoux et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>
- Image-guided superficial radiotherapy (IGSRT) has emerged as a treatment option for early-stage non-melanoma skin cancers (NMSCs), particularly beneficial for poor surgical candidates or patients who prefer to avoid surgery. For these early-stage cases, IGSRT represents a clinically equivalent alternative to Mohs micrographic surgery and demonstrates statistical superiority to non-image-guided superficial radiotherapy. <Paper corpusId="272548346" paperTitle="(Farberg et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>

## Molecular Imaging-Guided Approaches
- Novel approaches utilizing nanobodies (Nbs) in surgery for imaging guidance show promise, particularly in tumor visualization and resection. <Paper corpusId="238199127" paperTitle="(Naidoo et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>
- Dual-labeled antibodies combining fluorescent and radioactive labels enable multimodal imaging for improved tumor detection and removal. For example, trastuzumab labeled with both IRDye800CW (fluorescent) and 111In (radioactive) has been successfully used for specific visualization and image-guided resection of HER2-positive breast tumors. <Paper corpusId="238199127" paperTitle="(Naidoo et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="208190966" paperTitle="(Deken et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>
- In clinical settings, dual-labeled antibodies like In-DTPA-trastuzumab-IRDye800CW could potentially enhance both preoperative detection of tumors through SPECT/CT imaging and intraoperative localization using gamma probes and fluorescence imaging, improving complete tumor resection in patients with HER2-positive tumors. <Paper corpusId="208190966" paperTitle="(Deken et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

paper.title: Treatment of High-Risk Patients with Stage I Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.
paper.venue: Seminars in Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery

snippets: The Clinical Practice Standards Committee of the American Association for Thoracic Surgery assembled an expert panel and conducted a systematic review of the literature detailing studies directly comparing treatment options for high-risk patients with stage I non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). A systematic search was performed to identify publications comparing outcomes following image-guided thermal ablation (IGTA), stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (SABR), and sublobar resection-the main treatment options applicable to high-risk patients with stage I NSCLC.

paper.title: Systematic Review of the Comparative Studies of Image-guided Thermal Ablation, Stereotactic Radiosurgery, and Sublobar Resection for Treatment of High-Risk Patients with Stage I Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.
paper.venue: Seminars in Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery

snippets: In the case of radiotherapy treatment, technological advances have made it possible to have highly sophisticated image acquisition and treatment equipment, as well as planning systems that allow dose escalation using highly conformal techniques; however, increasing the dose also increases the risk of toxicity in healthy peripheral tissues as well as the probability of geometric uncertainties leading to underdosing in the target volume.

paper.title: Image-guided radiation therapy (IGRT) in prostate cancer in México, survey of SOMERA (Sociedad Mexicana de Radioterapeutas/Mexican Society of Radiation Oncologists) with recommendations on its implementation and process

snippets: Surgery plays multiple roles in cancer management, including prophylaxis if the organ is not crucial for survival; diagnosis, by taking a biopsy from a cancer patient; staging and measuring the extent of the tumor, including allowing the determination of the type of tumor, the growth extent, the size, the nodal involvement and the tumor distance and regional spread; as a definitive or curative treatment, by removing the entire tumor and the lymph nodes that are associated with it; as palliative care to reduce the symptoms and distress; as an adjuvant or supportive therapy, such as a tracheostomy and feeding tubes; as a reconstructive or rehabilitative therapy to reduce deformities; and as a salvage treatment for local disease recurrence, such as via a salvage radical cystectomy or mastectomy [5]

This approach has undergone substantial developments, such as the use of intensity-modulated radiation therapy [IMRT], image guided radiotherapy [IGRT], radioimmunotherapy, stereotactic radiosurgery [SRS], and stereotactic radiotherapy [SRT]

paper.title: The Pharmaceutical Applications of Next Generation Sequencing in Oncology Drug Designing and Development

snippets: Image-guided thermal ablation (IGTA) applied to pulmonary pathology is an alternative to surgery in high-risk patients with stage I non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Its application to lung neoplasm was first introduced in 2001 and has been implemented to treat metastatic disease to the lung or in select medically inoperable patients with peripheral stage I NSCLC. IGTA may also be an alternative to treat stage I NSCLC in non-operable patients with interstitial lung disease in whom a radiation modality is deemed too high risk. There are 3 methods of delivery: radiofrequency ablation (RFA), microwave ablation and cryoablation.

paper.title: Systematic Review of Image-guided Thermal Ablation for Treatment of High-Risk Patients with Stage I Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer.
paper.venue: Seminars in Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery

snippets: The expert panel identified sublobar resection, stereotactic ablative radiotherapy (SABR), and image-guided thermal ablation (IGTA) as modalities applicable in the treatment of high-risk patients with stage I NSCLC. The panel also identified lung-nodule-related factors that are important to consider in treatment selection.

paper.title: Treatment Selection for the High-risk Patient with Stage I Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer: Sublobar Resection, Stereotactic Ablative Radiotherapy or Image-guided Thermal Ablation?
paper.venue: Seminars in Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery

snippets: In the past 2 decades, new and improved imaging technologies and the use of breast cancer screening have led to the detection of smaller and earlier-stage breast cancers. Furthermore, there has been a trend toward less aggressive treatment of small breast cancers, which has led to the development of less invasive alternatives than surgery with promising effectiveness, and less morbidity. Many patients are not satisfied with the cosmetic outcome after breast-conservation therapy. Better cosmesis can be achieved with less invasive techniques. Moreover, less aggressive treatment options would be very useful in patients older than 70 years with comorbidities that make surgery a difficult and sometimes life-threatening treatment. Minimally invasive ablation techniques have been studied in early-stage small tumors with the goal of attaining efficacy similar to that of breast-conservation therapy.

paper.title: Image-guided ablation in breast cancer treatment.
paper.venue: Techniques in Vascular and Interventional Radiology

snippets: NMSCs have traditionally been treated with surgical excision, curettage, Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS), and superficial radiotherapy (SRT). Image-guided SRT (IGSRT) is a treatment option for poor surgical candidates or patients with low- or high-risk, early-stage NMSC who prefer to avoid surgery
For early-stage NMSCs, IGSRT is a clinically equivalent alternative to MMS and statistically significant in superiority to non-image-guided SRT.

paper.title: Nanobodies Enhancing Cancer Visualization, Diagnosis and Therapeutics

snippets: BackgroundCombining modalities using dual-labeled antibodies may allow preoperative and intraoperative tumor localization and could be used in image-guided surgery to improve complete tumor resection. Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody against the human epidermal growth factor-2 (HER2) receptor and dual-labeled trastuzumab with both a fluorophore (IRDye800CW) and a radioactive label (111In) can be used for multimodal imaging of HER2-positive breast cancer. The aim of this study was to demonstrate the feasibility of HER2-targeted multimodal imaging using [111In]In-DTPA-trastuzumab-IRDye800CW in an orthotopic breast cancer model.MethodsTrastuzumab was conjugated with p-isothiocyanatobenzyl (ITC)-diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (DTPA) and IRDye800CW-NHS ester and subsequently labeled with 111In. In a dose escalation study, the biodistribution of 10, 30, and 100 μg [111In]In-DTPA-trastuzumab-IRDye800CW was determined 48 h after injection in BALB/c nude mice with orthotopic high HER2-expressing tumors. Also, a biodistribution study was performed in a low HER2-expressing breast cancer model. In addition, multimodal image-guided surgery was performed in each group. Autoradiography, fluorescence microscopy, and immunohistochemically stained slices of the tumors were compared for co-localization of tumor tissue, HER2 expression, fluorescence, and radiosignal.ResultsBased on the biodistribution data, a 30 μg dose of dual-labeled trastuzumab (tumor-to-blood ratio 13 ± 2) was chosen for all subsequent studies. [111In]In-DTPA-trastuzumab-IRDye800CW specifically accumulated in orthotopic HER2-positive BT474 tumors (101 ± 7 %IA/g), whereas uptake in orthotopic low HER2-expressing MCF7 tumor was significantly lower (1.2 ± 0.2 %IA/g, p = 0.007). BT474 tumors could clearly be visualized with both micro-SPECT/CT, fluorescence imaging and subsequently, image-guided resection was performed. Immunohistochemical analyses of BT474 tumors demonstrated correspondence in fluorescence, radiosignal, and high HER2 expression.ConclusionsDual-labeled trastuzumab showed specific accumulation in orthotopic HER2-positive BT474 breast tumors with micro-SPECT/CT and fluorescence imaging and enabled image-guided tumor resection. In the clinical setting, [111In]In-DTPA-trastuzumab-IRDye800CW could be valuable for preoperative detection of (metastatic) tumors by SPECT/CT imaging, and intraoperative localization by using a gamma probe and fluorescence image-guided surgery to improve radical resection of tumor tissue in patients with HER2-positive tumors.

paper.title: Multimodal image-guided surgery of HER2-positive breast cancer using [111In]In-DTPA-trastuzumab-IRDye800CW in an orthotopic breast tumor model

sections.title: Emerging Technologies and Future Directions
sections.tldr: Image-guided surgery is evolving with dual-labeled antibody technologies that combine fluorescent and radioactive markers for more precise tumor visualization and resection. Future innovations include personalized approaches like sentinel node navigation for early-stage cancers and tailored chemotherapy regimens guided by imaging response assessment. (7 sources)
sections.text:
The landscape of image-guided cancer surgery continues to evolve with promising technological innovations aimed at improving surgical precision and patient outcomes. One significant advancement is the development of dual-labeled antibodies that combine fluorescent and radioactive labels for multimodal imaging. For example, trastuzumab labeled with both IRDye800CW (fluorescent) and 111In (radioactive) has demonstrated specific accumulation in HER2-positive breast tumors, enabling both pre-operative visualization through micro-SPECT/CT imaging and intraoperative guidance during tumor resection. <Paper corpusId="238199127" paperTitle="(Naidoo et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="208190966" paperTitle="(Deken et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

In clinical applications, these dual-labeled antibodies could significantly enhance surgical outcomes by allowing surgeons to detect tumors preoperatively with SPECT/CT imaging and then precisely locate and remove them intraoperatively using both gamma probes and fluorescence imaging. This approach shows particular promise for improving complete tumor resection in patients with HER2-positive malignancies. <Paper corpusId="238199127" paperTitle="(Naidoo et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="208190966" paperTitle="(Deken et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>

The concept of personalized cancer treatment is also advancing through image-guided approaches. For instance, sentinel node (SN) navigation surgery is emerging as a promising less invasive personalized treatment for early-stage esophageal cancer, though further multicenter trials using standardized protocols are still needed to establish its efficacy. <Paper corpusId="59410791" paperTitle="(Takeuchi et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> Similarly, for patients with unifocal breast cancer, wire-guided localization (WGL) combined with multi-detector computed tomography (MDCT) guided 3D reconstruction techniques are being developed to achieve improved cosmetic outcomes. <Paper corpusId="279367129" paperTitle="(Xia et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>

Adaptive treatment approaches guided by imaging are also showing promise. Researchers have evaluated an image-guided approach to tailor chemotherapy duration based on early response assessment. In this model, response to treatment is monitored every three cycles, and patients achieving radiologic complete response (rCR) are referred for surgery rather than completing a predetermined number of chemotherapy cycles. This approach potentially reduces unnecessary treatment and associated toxicity while maintaining efficacy. <Paper corpusId="257326144" paperTitle="(Voort et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>

In ovarian cancer management, fluorescence image-guided surgery represents a promising intraoperative guidance technique to improve debulking completeness, which is considered the only modifiable prognostic factor for patients with advanced disease. <Paper corpusId="52270092" paperTitle="(Lorenzo et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> This approach could potentially enhance the surgeon's ability to identify and remove microscopic disease that might otherwise be missed with conventional visual and tactile assessment.

Radiation therapy is also evolving with technological advancements that complement surgical approaches. These include intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT), image-guided radiotherapy (IGRT), radioimmunotherapy, stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS), and stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT). <Paper corpusId="55378429" paperTitle="(Nawab, 2015)" isShortName></Paper> These technologies allow for more precise targeting of tumors while sparing surrounding healthy tissues, potentially improving both the efficacy and safety profiles of cancer treatments.

As these emerging technologies continue to develop and undergo clinical validation, they promise to further refine the application of image-guided surgery across different cancer types and stages, potentially expanding treatment options for patients and improving long-term outcomes.

paper.title: Abstract P5-09-03: Localization combined with multidetector CT 3-dimensional image reconstruction guided precision breast conserving surgery versus conventional breast conserving surgery: cosmetic analysis of the single center, prospective, cohort study

snippets: We evaluated an image-guided approach to tailor chemotherapy duration based on the identification of early complete responders

Response to treatment was monitored every three cycles and patients were referred for surgery in case of a radiologic complete response (rCR) or after a maximum of 9 cycles. RCR was defined as the absence of pathological enhancement on MRI breast plus negative vacuum assisted core biopsies in case of hormone-receptor positive (HR+) tumors. In addition, negative fine needle aspiration or lymph node biopsy was required in patients with nodal involvement at baseline.

paper.title: Abstract PD18-06: Image-guided optimization of neoadjuvant chemotherapy duration in stage II and III HER2-positive breast cancer: radiologic and pathologic complete response (pCR) rates in the multicenter phase 2 TRAIN-3 study (BOOG 2018-01)

snippets: Surgical management of OC remains the cornerstone treatment of the disease (Figure 1). An adequate full surgical staging in women with early stage disease has been demonstrated to improve outcome. In fact, complete surgical cytoreduction is considered to be the only modifiable prognostic factor for patients with advanced disease (Stuart et al., 2011). OC surgery is essentially a laparotomic surgery; the laparoscopic technique can be used in the early stages, in restaging surgery, and in advanced stages for the assessment of disease to evaluate the possibility of optimal primary cytoreduction (Fagotti et al., 2016)(Fagotti et al., 2013) (Figure 2). Goals of primary surgery for ovarian cancer are proper staging (in early disease) and optimal cytoreduction/debulking (in advanced disease). Optimal debulking surgery is defined as surgery that results in no macroscopic residual disease. Primary debulking surgery (PDS) followed by platinum-based chemotherapy is the standard treatment for patients with advanced disease. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NACT) followed by interval debulking surgery (IDS) is an alternative treatment option for patients who are unlikely to undergo PDS. Fluorescence image-guided surgery represents a promising intraoperative guidance technique to improve debulking completeness.

paper.title: Imaging and therapy of ovarian cancer: clinical application of nanoparticles and future perspectives
